description: Basic concepts and principles of chemistry and their applications in chemistry and closely-related fields. The first term emphasizes the understanding of chemical reactions through atomic and molecular structure. This is a university level course, treating the material in sufficient depth so that students can solve chemical problems and can understand the principles involved in their solution. It includes an introduction to condensed matter. This course is suitable for majors or non-majors and is recommended to satisfy either major or preprofessional requirements for general chemistry. This course is presented for students with high school chemistry and calculus. Students with a lesser background than this should take Chemistry 100.
name: GENERAL CHEMISTRY I

values.comments:
Topics covered include basic concepts and principles of chemistry and their
applications in chemistry and closely-related fields. The first term emphasizes the
understanding of chemical reactions through atomic and molecular structure. This is a
university level course, treating the material in sufficient depth so that students can solve
chemical problems and can understand the principles involved in their solution. It
includes an introduction to condensed matter. This course is suitable for majors or nonmajors
and is recommended to satisfy either major or pre-professional requirements for
general chemistry.
The course was described as not having a “clear direction” and the material
deemed very “difficult.” It was said to be a very “theoretically” based and not very math
heavy, so was recommended for those looking for a less math-intensive CHEM101
section.
Professor Topp was described as very “knowledgeable” and very willing to help
students. However, some students noted that his lecture style was very “monotone” and
“boring.” Some students did describe Professor Topp as “likeable” and funny, however.
This course fulfills the Physical World Requirement. This course is presented for
students with high school chemistry and calculus. Students with a lesser background than
this should take Chemistry 100.

This course focuses on basic concepts and principles of chemistry and their
applications in chemistry and closely related fields. The first term emphasizes the
understanding of chemical reactions through atomic and molecular structure. This is a
university level course, treating the material in sufficient depth so that students can solve
chemical problems and can understand the principles involved in their solution. It
includes an introduction to condensed matter.
Many students found the content of this course to be rather dry, however,
recognized that the information gained from this course was necessary to understand
more advanced topics in chemistry. The course was said to be very theoretical.
Professor Topp was described as very knowledgeable and always well prepared
with material. His lectures were occasionally confusing, and it was necessary to review
his lecture notes multiple times in order to understand what he is getting at sometimes,
though this is probably to be expected with almost any chemistry course. He was very
helpful in office hours and has a great personality, which made up for the generally
unexciting lectures. His tests were very difficult, though they got easier as students
become accustomed to how they are designed.
This course is suitable for majors or non-majors and is recommended to satisfy
either major or pre-professional requirements for general chemistry. This course is
presented for students with high school chemistry and calculus. Students with a lesser
background than this should take Chemistry 100. This course fulfills the physical world
sector. Many students found the exams in this course to be very difficult, but fair.

This course covers basic concepts and principles of chemistry and their
applications in chemistry and closely related fields. The first term emphasizes the
understanding of chemical reactions through atomic and molecular structure. This is a
university level course, treating the material in sufficient depth so that students can solve
chemical problems and can understand the principles involved in their solution. It
includes an introduction to condensed matter.
Some students found the class to be “informative,” “fun and understandable,”
though the majority thought it was fairly uninteresting. Students who were not interested
in chemistry “did not find the course extremely stimulating.”
While most students agreed that Dr. Park was “really sweet and always willing to
help,” many felt that “she has trouble expressing herself, and has a thick accent.” Her
lectures were “hard to follow,” forcing many students to rely on the textbook more than
they would have liked. Dr. Park was described as “enthusiastic,” though often this
enthusiasm could not overcome the “language barrier” between her and her students.
Students found this course to be “very difficult.” For the most part, Dr. Park was
described as a “reasonable marker,” though some felt her tests were not fair, due to how
difficult it was to understand her lectures. This course is suitable for majors or nonmajors
and is recommended to satisfy either major or pre-professional requirements for
general chemistry. This course is presented for students with high school chemistry and
calculus. Students with a lesser background than this should take Chemistry 100.

This course covers basic concepts and principles of chemistry and their
applications in chemistry and closely related fields. The first term emphasizes the
understanding of chemical reactions through atomic and molecular structure. This is a
university level course, treating the material in sufficient depth so that students can solve
chemical problems and can understand the principles involved in their solution. It also
includes an introduction to condensed matter.
Students generally found this class to be “enjoyable” despite its difficulty, and
they reported learning “a great deal” over the course of the semester. Students described
it as an “interesting and educational” course that covered a substantial amount of
material.
Students generally found Dr. Pietrovito to be “difficult to understand” and not
very engaging as a lecturer. Many commented that students frequently fell asleep during
his lectures. Several also noted that he often “rambled” and had “difficulty
communicating the material effectively.” However, students conceded that Dr. Pietrovito
knew the course material very well and was a “nice guy” who was “extremely willing” to
answer students’ questions during office hours. However, he did not answer questions
during lecture. A large number of students spoke very highly of Dr. Pietrovito’s online
notes for the course, which students found very useful in studying for exams
This course fulfills the Physical World sector requirement. It is suitable for
majors or non-majors and is recommended to satisfy either major or pre-professional
requirements for general chemistry. This course is presented for students with a
background in high school chemistry and calculus; students with a lesser background
than should take Chemistry 100. Students generally described this course as very
“challenging,” “much harder than expected,” and as having a “harsh curve.” However,
even though exams were “difficult,” students always knew what to expect on them, and
most students said that grades were fair and quite reflective of their efforts. The course
requires “a lot of dedication,” and students found that practice problems were “the key to
success” in this course. It was described as a “good intro course” and as a “very good
course for chemistry majors.” Engineering students also found this course “useful.”

This course covers basic concepts and principles of chemistry and their
applications in chemistry and closely-related fields. The first term emphasizes the
understanding of chemical reactions through atomic and molecular structure. This is a
university level course, treating the material in sufficient depth so that students can solve
chemical problems and can understand the principles involved in their solution. It
includes an introduction to condensed matter. This course is suitable for majors or nonmajors
and is recommended to satisfy either major or pre-professional requirements for
general chemistry. This course is presented for students with high school chemistry and
calculus. Students with a lesser background than this should take Chemistry 100.
Students who took this class described it as “informative,” but a bit “dull.” Many
students stressed that they learned an incredible amount that they did not know before,
but required strong background knowledge in order to understand some of the more
difficult subjects. Students stressed the importance of keeping up with your work and
how falling behind could have a snowballing effect on the rest of the class.
Students described Professor Davies as the better of the two professors. He
described the subjects in an interesting way and was very helpful during office hours.
Professor Davies often connected the material in class to real world applications in order
to make the material more interesting.
Most students described this class as difficult. One student mentioned,
“background material is practically a necessity to get anything above a B.” Students
stressed that as the course progressed, it became more and more difficult. The course
was taken by both majors and non-majors.

This class teaches basic concepts and principles of chemistry and their
applications in chemistry and closely-related fields. The first half of the semester focuses
on understanding chemical reactions through atomic and molecular structure. This course
treats the material in sufficient depth so that students can solve chemical problems and
understand the principles involved in their solution.
Students found that Professor Blasie went into a lot of depth – many felt that the
detail was unnecessary, and that other professors of CHEM 101 weren’t doing the same.
Most agreed that the course material strayed far from the textbook, making it difficult to
follow along.
Students described Professor Blasie as “difficult to connect to” and
“condescending.” While they agreed he was an expert in his field, they didn’t feel
comfortable asking questions. Many students reported that he was “very difficult to
understand” and that he showed “no interest in the course or the students.” However, a
couple of students did note the usefulness of office hours for understanding the material.
Students did not recommend this class and found the grading to be extremely
tough.
